conclusion: Introduction to the problem with hemispheres A and B, their masses, and friction conditions.
Understanding that the hemispheres are in equilibrium and frictional force is at maximum.
Plan to analyze forces starting with hemisphere B.
Hemisphere B has mass 2m and is smooth, so no friction with hemisphere A.
Hemisphere B has weight 2mg downward and normal force F along the line connecting centers at 30°.
Sum of forces in horizontal and vertical directions for hemisphere B is zero.
Horizontal force equation for B: FN - F cos(30°) = 0.
Vertical force equation for B: F sin(30°) - 2mg = 0.
Calculate F from vertical equation: F = 4mg.
Calculate FN from horizontal equation: FN = 2mg√3.
Plan to analyze forces on hemisphere A.
Hemisphere A has mass m and friction with the left wall.
Forces on A: weight mg downward, normal force FN1 right, frictional force Ff upward, normal force from B 4mg at 30°.
Sum of forces in horizontal and vertical directions for hemisphere A must be zero.
Horizontal force equation for A: FN1 - F cos(30°) = 0.
Vertical force equation for A: F sin(30°) + Ff - mg = 0.
Calculate FN1 from horizontal equation: FN1 = 2mg√3.
Attempt to calculate Ff from vertical equation, resulting in Ff = -mg.
Realization of a mistake in calculation.
